Situation1: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Situation2: They encounter a situation where a friend is being treated unfairly and feel a stronger responsibility to intervene or speak up.
Story:
I sat at my desk, headset pressing into my ears, the script for our new service open in front of me. The calls came in one after another, each prospect firing off technical questions that the script only half-answered. My manager expected me to keep the conversation moving, to handle objections smoothly, but I could hear the uncertainty in the customers’ voices. I wanted to be honest, to admit when I didn’t know something, but the pressure to stick to the script was intense.

Then, during my break, I overheard a supervisor speaking harshly to my friend Priya, blaming her for a mistake she didn’t make. As a Hindu, I was taught to stand up for dharma, to act with integrity and protect others from injustice. My heart pounded as I watched Priya’s face fall. I felt torn—my job demanded I stay in my lane, avoid conflict, and focus on my own performance. But my conscience screamed at me to intervene, to speak up for what was right. The weight of these conflicting expectations pressed down on me, leaving me paralyzed between my duty as an employee and my responsibility as a human being.
